newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Ireland launches 100-punt note, last before EMU.
newsitem.headline: Ireland launches 100-punt note, last before EMU.

text.p: The Central Bank of Ireland launched a new 100-punt note Friday, possibly the last Irish banknote to be issued if Ireland succeeds in qualifying for European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).
"If European integration moves ahead according to plan, this will be the last Irish bank note to be issued," central bank Gov. Maurice O'Connell said at the launch.
"The timetable for economic and monetary union provides that the Euro banknotes will be in circulation by the beginning of the year 2002."
O'Connell said the changeover would be a huge logistical exercise and that Ireland was preparing for it on the assumption that it would participate in a single currency.
The 100-punt note, worth about $62 at current exchange rates, features Charles Stewart Parnell, one of the great political figures of 19th-century Ireland.
It is the fifth and final note in a series which has seen the security features of Irish banknotes substantially upgraded and the size of the notes reduced for greater convenience.
